content: The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" is cited as the short title. It amends Section 503 of title 31, United States Code, to include governmentwide standards for program and project management for executive agencies under the Deputy Director for Management. The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" amends Section 503 of title 31, United States Code, to include governmentwide standards for program and project management for executive agencies under the Deputy Director for Management. The Act outlines guidelines for overseeing implementation, chairing the Program Management Policy Council, establishing standards and policies, and engaging with the private sector to improve Federal program and project management. The Program Management Improvement Accountability Act includes provisions to engage with the private sector, conduct portfolio reviews of high-risk programs, assess program management quality annually, and establish a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management. The Program Management Improvement Accountability Act aims to assess program management quality annually and establish a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management. The Program Management Improvement Accountability Act requires the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget to issue standards, policies, and guidelines within 1 year of enactment. Regulations must be issued within 90 days after the standards are released. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Program Management Policy Council, will issue regulations to implement the requirements of section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include Program Management Improvement Officers and the Program Management Policy Council. The Program Management Improvement Officers and Program Management Policy Council are established under Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code. Each agency must designate a senior executive as the Program Management Improvement Officer to implement program management policies. The agency designated under paragraph (1) must implement program management policies and develop a strategy to enhance the role of program managers, including providing enhanced training and educational opportunities. The agency must provide training in relevant competencies for program and project managers in the private sector, focusing on cost containment for large projects and programs. The agency aims to enhance program management by mentoring current and future program managers, improving career paths, recruiting highly qualified individuals, sharing best practices, and providing common templates and tools. The agency aims to enhance program management by sharing best practices, common templates, and tools for data gathering and analysis. This subsection does not apply to the Department of Defense if similar provisions are already in place. The Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics is designated as the Program Management Improvement Officer. The Program Management Policy Council is established in the Office of Management and Budget to improve agency practices related to program and project management. The Program Management Policy Council, established in the Office of Management and Budget, serves as the principal interagency forum for improving agency practices related to program and project management. It advises the Deputy Director for Management, reviews high-risk programs, and discusses topics like career development for the workforce. The Program Management Policy Council advises on workforce development needs, policy for program management improvement, and challenges in program management across agencies. It also reviews governmentwide standards for program management transparency and information published on the Office of Management and Budget's website. The Council is composed of five members from the Office of Management and Budget. The Program Management Policy Council advises on workforce development needs, policy for program management improvement, and challenges in program management across agencies. It is composed of five members from the Office of Management and Budget, including the Deputy Director for Management, the Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, the Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, the Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and the Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management. The Program Management Policy Council is composed of various agency officers and employees designated by the Chairperson, with the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget serving as the Chairperson and a Vice Chairperson elected by the members for a term of up to 1 year. The Chairperson of the Council is responsible for presiding over meetings, setting the agenda, directing the work of the Council, and establishing subgroups as needed. The Council must meet at least twice per fiscal year and can convene at the Chairperson's or majority of members' request. The Council, chaired by the Chairperson, must meet at least twice per fiscal year and can convene at the request of the Chairperson or majority members. The head of each agency with a Project Management Improvement Officer on the Council must provide administrative support as needed. A report must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Officer designated under section 1126(a)(1) of title 31, United States Code, must submit a report to Congress containing the strategy developed under section 1126(a)(2)(B) of such title. Program and Project Management Personnel Standards require regulations to be issued within 180 days after the standards, policies, and guidelines are issued under section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will issue regulations within 180 days to identify key skills and competencies, establish a new job series for program and project management, and create a new career path for managers within an agency. The Government Accountability Office will issue a report on the effectiveness of policies for program and project management within federal agencies, in conjunction with the High Risk list.
